content.webTitle: Tennis: Dokic gets back with father as ranking drops

fields.headline: Dokic gets back with father as ranking drops into three figures
fields.bodyText: The twisting tale of Jelena Dokic's career appears to have taken a backward turn with reports from her native Yugoslavia that she has reconciled with her father Damir and plans to resume a coaching relationship with him at the start of the 2005 season. "I'm starting from scratch," said Dokic, according to Belgrade's Sport newspaper. "I have two to three months to prepare before my next tournament." The same newspaper also carried quotes from her father, who reportedly said: "Whatever happened, happened. Jelena had shown that she's a great player. She was in crisis. The time has come to correct that." Dokic and her father have been estranged for much of the last two years, ever since a public row with him and her mother Liliana during an event in Filderstadt in October 2002, which led to both parents being refused credentials for tournaments where she was playing. Her father's outbursts at tournaments, including Wimbledon and the US Open, lead to the WTA banning him from the circuit for six months, yet his daughter stood by him. Since splitting from her father, Dokic has tried working with a string of other coaches while her ranking has sunk from a career high of No4 in the world to No105. With her father's help she won five singles titles and was a semi-finalist at Wimbledon, results which contrast sharply with this season's efforts. She has not won a match since April and suffered eight first-round defeats in a row. Dokic could not be reached for comment last night.
